sentences.sentence: Social media Claims the government's bill is about censorship of opinion misread the legislation and fail to properly understand the threats to our society and our democracy.The Albanese government's Combating Misinformation and Disinformation Bill, currently out for consultation, is facing opposition on the grounds that it is a threat to free speech.This opposition not only misunderstands the bill's nature but also illustrates a naive understanding of the threats to our society and our democracy.Democracy is under threat in many parts of the world.Many people I have spoken to in the United States, for example, consider disinformation on digital platforms is increasing polarisation and so threatening their democracy.They cite, for example, both foreign governments and extremist groups in the US injecting false information, or disinformation, to create or amplify particular concerns with the objective of fracturing US society.

Without any regulatory response, perhaps due to the First Amendment, those doing this in the US get a "free hit".In response to the parliament's select committee on foreign interference through social media, agencies in Australia have sounded the alarm.The Department of Home Affairs says: "Foreign actors... spread mis- and disinformation through social media in order to advance their own interests at the expense of Australia.

"As an example, it cites an Australian Strategic Policy Institute study that "reported that Australian mining company Lynas Rare Earths was targeted by an information operation that used environmental, political and health concerns to undermine efforts to diversify global rare-earth supply chains.
"Likewise, ASIO told the same committee that "foreign powers seek to do Australia harm through... social media platforms...
Many of the deliberate design features of the platforms... can exacerbate the risk of foreign interference.

"Such concerns, particularly about our democracy, were why the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission recommended in its 2019 report on digital platforms, in response to its wide-ranging terms of reference, that the Australian Communications and Media Authority be given powers to begin to address these issues.The then Coalition government accepted the ACCC's proposals, and the current bill is in accordance with the 2019 recommendations and the direction set by the previous government.
Since 2019, the concerns that prompted the bill have only heightened.

Generative AI, for example, will amplify these concerns considerably as it can make disinformation more credible and difficult to identify.The current bill is directed solely at encouraging digital platform providers to have robust and transparent systems and measures in place to address what the platforms consider misinformation and disinformation on their services; it does not involve the ACMA directly regulating individual pieces of content.To be clear, the ACMA will not have the power to request specific content or posts be removed from digital platform services.The bill puts the onus on the platforms.

It proposes giving the ACMA powers to gather information or require digital platform providers to keep certain records about matters regarding misinformation and disinformation.They would also enable the ACMA to request platforms to develop a code of practice covering measures to combat misinformation and disinformation, which the ACMA could register and enforce.Any ACMA powers go to the adequacy of systems, not content.The systems to be put in place by the platforms relating to misinformation or disinformation apply only when information is untrue, so matters of opinion are irrelevant, and they must also meet a threshold of being likely to cause or contribute to serious harm.Further, these are judgments to be made by the platforms, not the ACMA; the platforms must assess whether the high bar of "serious harm" is met.

That is, the bill is about ensuring the platforms have systems in place to deal with disinformation, and that these are transparent.The obligations are similar to those that apply to large online platforms in Europe under the European Commission's Digital Services Act.Governments face two choices on these vital but difficult issues.First, do nothing and leave it to the platforms themselves to decide whether to do anything at all, and if so, what.
In my view this is an abrogation of responsibility by government.Or the government can seek to intervene in some way.
By simply requiring processes and transparency, this bill takes a low-key approach.More may be needed, but this can be debated later.

Opposing this bill on the basis of free speech is like asking your soldiers on the front line to lay down their arms because of an overarching belief in peace.Rod Sims is a professor at the ANU's Crawford School of Public Policy.
He was chairman of the ACCC from 2011 to 2022.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
documents.inputText: Social media Claims the government's bill is about censorship of opinion misread the legislation and fail to properly understand the threats to our society and our democracy.The Albanese government's Combating Misinformation and Disinformation Bill, currently out for consultation, is facing opposition on the grounds that it is a threat to free speech.This opposition not only misunderstands the bill's nature but also illustrates a naive understanding of the threats to our society and our democracy.Democracy is under threat in many parts of the world.Many people I have spoken to in the United States, for example, consider disinformation on digital platforms is increasing polarisation and so threatening their democracy.They cite, for example, both foreign governments and extremist groups in the US injecting false information, or disinformation, to create or amplify particular concerns with the objective of fracturing US society. Without any regulatory response, perhaps due to the First Amendment, those doing this in the US get a "free hit".In response to the parliament's select committee on foreign interference through social media, agencies in Australia have sounded the alarm.The Department of Home Affairs says: "Foreign actors ... spread mis- and disinformation through social media in order to advance their own interests at the expense of Australia."As an example, it cites an Australian Strategic Policy Institute study that "reported that Australian mining company Lynas Rare Earths was targeted by an information operation that used environmental, political and health concerns to undermine efforts to diversify global rare-earth supply chains."Likewise, ASIO told the same committee that "foreign powers seek to do Australia harm through ... social media platforms ... Many of the deliberate design features of the platforms ... can exacerbate the risk of foreign interference."Such concerns, particularly about our democracy, were why the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission recommended in its 2019 report on digital platforms, in response to its wide-ranging terms of reference, that the Australian Communications and Media Authority be given powers to begin to address these issues.The then Coalition government accepted the ACCC's proposals, and the current bill is in accordance with the 2019 recommendations and the direction set by the previous government. Since 2019, the concerns that prompted the bill have only heightened. Generative AI, for example, will amplify these concerns considerably as it can make disinformation more credible and difficult to identify.The current bill is directed solely at encouraging digital platform providers to have robust and transparent systems and measures in place to address what the platforms consider misinformation and disinformation on their services; it does not involve the ACMA directly regulating individual pieces of content.To be clear, the ACMA will not have the power to request specific content or posts be removed from digital platform services.The bill puts the onus on the platforms. It proposes giving the ACMA powers to gather information or require digital platform providers to keep certain records about matters regarding misinformation and disinformation.They would also enable the ACMA to request platforms to develop a code of practice covering measures to combat misinformation and disinformation, which the ACMA could register and enforce.Any ACMA powers go to the adequacy of systems, not content.The systems to be put in place by the platforms relating to misinformation or disinformation apply only when information is untrue, so matters of opinion are irrelevant, and they must also meet a threshold of being likely to cause or contribute to serious harm.Further, these are judgments to be made by the platforms, not the ACMA; the platforms must assess whether the high bar of "serious harm" is met. That is, the bill is about ensuring the platforms have systems in place to deal with disinformation, and that these are transparent.The obligations are similar to those that apply to large online platforms in Europe under the European Commission's Digital Services Act.Governments face two choices on these vital but difficult issues.First, do nothing and leave it to the platforms themselves to decide whether to do anything at all, and if so, what. In my view this is an abrogation of responsibility by government.Or the government can seek to intervene in some way. By simply requiring processes and transparency, this bill takes a low-key approach.More may be needed, but this can be debated later. Opposing this bill on the basis of free speech is like asking your soldiers on the front line to lay down their arms because of an overarching belief in peace.Rod Sims is a professor at the ANU's Crawford School of Public Policy. He was chairman of the ACCC from 2011 to 2022.
